comment.author: 58584977@N05
comment.text: Harry Amyas Leigh Herschel Wade (b. 1873), fourth son of Sir Thomas Francis Wade (1818-1895), the diplomat and Sinologist ("Wade" of the Wade-Giles system of romanization), and his wife Amelia Herschel (1841-1926), daughter of the astronomer John Herschel. Harry was born in Peking (now Beijing); Sir Thomas retired to England in 1888, the same year Harry entered Harrow (along with classmate Winston Churchill!). Harry left Harrow in 1890 and joined the army in 1893, rising to the rank of major by 1910, and was decorated for his service during the Nile Expedition and the Boer War (his eldest brother Alexander was killed in action in the latter conflict). Cf. The Harrow School Register, 1800-1911, 3rd ed., ed. M.G. Dauglish and P.K. Stephenson (London: Longmans, Green & Co., 1911). According to this website, a man of that name married Dorothy Cazalet (b. 1888) at Geneva Cathedral in 1924. It is certain that Harry's brother Edward (1872-1945), an astronomer, retired to Geneva in 1925 (cf. his obituary in Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society, v. 106, p.39).

comment.author: 58584977@N05
comment.text: "Peking (now Beijing)" in terms of romanization only, of course -- 北京 is "Peking" in Chinese Postal Map romanization (based on the Wade-Giles system), now superseded by pinyin, which gives "Beijing".

comment.author: 58584977@N05
comment.text: Further information on Harry Wade: he also served in the Great War (on the staff of the 1st Army Corps in France and then as military attaché in Denmark) and was brevetted Lieutenant-Colonel in 1918. In that same year he led a three-member diplomatic mission to Poland and subsequently accompanied Ignacy Paderewski on his return to that country in 1919. (Cf. C. Fink, Defending the Rights of Others (Cambridge: Cambridge UP, 2004), p. 121-126.) Wade appears to have had some talent for writing on military subjects (cf. these two articles reprinted in The Britannica Year-Book 1913. He edited the Army Review in 1912 and the League of Nations Union in 1919; after leaving the army in 1921, he was an official of the League of Nations and then of the World Court until his retirement in 1937 (which inclines me to believe the report of his marriage in Geneva in 1924). His obituary in the Times of London notes that he was one of the League's chief "spontaneous translators;" the writer Maurice Collis also testified to his linguistic skills by thanking Wade "for his help in deciphering some old Portuguese documents" in the Acknowledgments to The Grand Peregrination (London: Faber & Faber, 1949), a biography of Fernão Mendes Pinto. Wade was appointed research officer of the United Nations War Crimes Commission in 1944, took part in the Nuremberg trials, and wrote chapters 6 and 7, as well as some of the appendices, of History of the United Nations War Crimes Commission and the Development of the Laws of War (London: HMSO, 1948). He died in 1959. Cf. J.H. Stogdon, ed., The Harrow School Register, 2nd ser. (London: Longmans, Green & Co., 1925), v. 2 (1885-1925), p. 42; "Lt.-Col. H.A.L.H. Wade," The Times (London), 21 November 1959; p. 10. (Somebody should write a biography of this guy. It sounds as if he led a pretty interesting life.)

comment.author: 58584977@N05
comment.text:
One last thing: Erwin Canham, long-time editor of The Christian Science Monitor, presents this vignette of Wade as a Christian Scientist in Geneva:
A regular member [of the church] was Col. H.H. Wade, the League [of Nations]'s chief interpreter. He had the task of turning the French speeches into English and he handled M. Briand's organ-toned oratory with circumspection. Often, during the Wednesday-evening testimony meetings at church, Colonel Wade would rise and convert into either English or French some particularly helpful testimony of healing.
Cf. E.D. Canham, "A Christian Scientist's Life," in The Christian Science Way of Life by DeWitt John (Englewood Cliffs, NJ: Prentice-Hall, 1962), p. 213.

comment.author: 58584977@N05
comment.text: Further marital information: in 1908 Wade married Kathleen Adelaide Herschel (1884-1959), by whom he had a daughter, the novelist Rosalind Herschel Wade (1909-1989), aka Catharine Carr, who married the poet William Kean Seymour (1887-1975).

Established heading: Neale, Erskine, ǂd 1804-1883. Probably Sir John Pirie (1781-1851), Lord Mayor of London 1841-1842, who received his baronetcy in 1842. (Prior to that he would have been Mr. John Pirie.). See this website for a very brief biography; also his obituary in The Gentleman's Magazine, v. 35, new series (1851), p. 551.]

comment.author: 58584977@N05
comment.text: Pulling all the dates together, this letter was probably written in the 1840s -- not before 1842 when John Pirie became Sir John Pirie and not after his death in 1851.

comment.author: 58584977@N05
comment.text: Envelope addressed to "Elder Esq[ui]re care of Messrs. Smith, Elder & Co. 65 Cornhill London" with cancelled penny red stamp (issued from 1841-1879) in upper right corner. Smith, Elder & Co. was a notable 19th-century British publishing firm founded by George Smith (1789-1846) -- later succeeded by his son, George Murray Smith (1824-1901) -- and Alexander Elder (1790-1876). The firm took up residence at 65 Cornhill in 1824 and remained there until 1868, when it moved to Waterloo Place. Cf. George Murray Smith's entry in the ODNB. Per the letter's signature, the hand is that of "Erskine Neale" -- probably Erskine Neale (1804–1883), Anglican clergyman and author, whose work The Life-Book of a Labourer was published by Smith, Elder & Co. in 1839. Established heading: Smith, Elder, and Co. Established heading: Neale, Erskine, 1804-1883.

George G. Kennaway -
From His Mother.
April 1855.

comment.author: 58584977@N05
comment.text:
Probably George Glass Kennaway (ca. 1824-1868?) of Hoopern House, Exeter, Devon, UK, son of the Exeter solicitor and liberal politician Mark Kennaway and his wife Harriet (née Codrington). George matriculated at Christ Church College, Oxford, in 1842 at age 18 and took his BA in 1846 and his MA in 1848; cf. J. Foster, Alumni Oxonienses (Oxford: Parker & Co., 1888), v. 2, p. 786. He contributed to the restoration of Wynard's Chapel (also called Trinity Chapel, but not to be confused with the nearby Holy Trinity Church) in Exeter, where he is buried. According to B. Cresswell, Exeter Churches (Exeter: J.G. Commin, 1908) p. 61, his epitaph reads:
Here lieth George Glass Kennaway, of Christchurch, Oxon. Eldest son of Mark Kennaway of Hoopern Esqr., by Harriet Codrington second daughter of George Daniel of this city. A cheerful restorer of this ancient chapel and Gods House, a liberal benefactor to the pries [sic] and the poor. He deceased Dec. xxxi mdccclxvii in the xlvi year of his age.
For "mdccclxvii" read "1868," I think, judging from the fact that his death at age 45 (the 46th year of his age) was registered in early 1869; cf. information transcribed by FreeBMD from the civil registration index of births, marriages and deaths for England and Wales. Harvard Library MS Eng 898 ("Sonnets, and Poems, written by John Bampfylde Esqr.") evidently has Kennaways ownership inscription, dated 1863 at Hoopern House. Cf. C.R. Woodring, "Charles Lamb in the Harvard Library" in Harvard Library Bulletin 10.2 (1956), p. 210, n. 5. For his mother, Harriet Codrington Kennaway (d. 1861), see her obituary notice in The London Review 3 (1861), p. 332.

comment.author: 58584977@N05
comment.text: The foundation of the Jesuitenkolleg Augsburg (also known as St. Salvator) was underwritten by a monetary donation from the heirs of Christoph Fugger (d. 1579) and a grant of land by Philipp Eduard und Octavian Secundus Fugger in 1580. The institution opened its doors in 1582 and survived the release of the Jesuits from their vows by the Bishop of Augsburg in 1776 to be finally closed in 1807, when (according to the Stadtlexikon Augsburg), its Lyceum was merged with the Dillinger Lyzeum and its Gymnasium with the evangelical Gymnasium bei St. Anna. Narziss Lauginger (d. 1534/39) was the son of a prominent mercantile family in Augsburg; cf. its entry in the Augsburger Stadtlexikon. (The previous mistaken transcription of his name as "Maxi[milian] Longinger" was taken from L.W. Riley, "The French Prose Alexander Romance," The Library, 5th series, 20 (1965), p. 243-244.)

I agree about the et suor[um] and I am changing the last name in the title to Safanius.

comment.author: 58654589@N08
comment.text: transcription: "Ex lib. mon[aster]rii [Sanc]ti Martini(?) a Canigone(?)" heading: Abbaye Saint-Martin du Canigou (Casteil, France) Cf. stmartinducanigou.org/ (featuring the bells of ...! [warning: lower volume levels before clicking on the link]) "History The original Romanesque style monastery was built from 1005 to 1009 by Guifred, Count of Cerdanya (Fr. Cerdagne), in atonement for the murder of his son and was populated by Benedictine monks. In 1049, Guifred, Count of Cerdanya, died at the monastery he had built. In 1051 a messenger set forth to visit religious houses throughout Europe to solicit prayers for his dead master. He brought a parchment upon which at each stop were added words of prayer and respect. This parchment has survived and scholars (including Léopold Delisle with his Rouleaux des Morts du IX au XV Siecle of 1866) have used it to discover differences in culture between northern and southern Europe in a single given year. Some of the discoveries from this important document include that southern culture was more staid and bound by custom while the northern culture more free form and experimental in their writing styles, use of words and grammar. The monastery was damaged in the Catalan earthquake of 1428. The monastery was secularized in 1782 by Louis XVI. The monastery was abandoned by the monks in 1783-1785 and fell into disrepair. During the Terror, the abbey was closed, and its contents scattered. The buildings were then transformed into a stone quarry for nearby residents, the capitals of the cloister were looted, as well as sculptures and furniture. In 1902, the bishop of Elne and Perpignan, because of his Catalan background, began to restore the ruins radically, work that was completed in 1932. Today it is occupied by the Catholic Community of the Beatitudes." Cf. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martin-du-Canigou pictures of & directions to: www.sacred-destinations.com/france/saint-martin-du-canigou

comment.author: 58654589@N08
58584977@N05
comment.text:
Re: Augustinians--Recollect and/or Discalced. They are certainly separate orders now (cf. their webpages, here for the OAR and here for the Asian province of the OAD, each with potted history). John Gavigan, OSA, also distinguishes them in v. 4 of the History of the Order of St. Augustine:
Both congregations were founded as a stricter form of life, the Recollects in 1588, the Discalced in 1593.... Although subject to the Augustinian prior general, both groups were under the direct jurisdiction of a vicar general since the 17th century.... [In 1911, t]he vicar general of the Recollects requested several favors of Pius X. The first was the extension to the Recollects of all exemptions granted to the Discalced Augustinians of Italy, especially with regard to subjection to the Augustinian prior general. The second was the abrogation of two papal documents of 1602 which confirmed the power of the Augustinian prior general over the Recollects. The third was the granting to the Recollect vicar general of all the privileges enjoyed by the Augustinian prior general with regard to sodalities and confraternities connected with the saints of the order; and that all the spiritual favors granted to the Augustinians be also given to the Recollects. On July 18, the pope granted these requests ... The final step toward complete separation from the Augustinian order and the foundation of a new order was taken by the Recollects in the following year. They requested and obtained from the same pope on September 16 the apostolic brief Religiosas familias [which established the Recollects under their own prior general with the same privileges and responsibilities as the Augustinian prior general]. Hence, the Recollect J.A. Salazar rightly calls his confreres a judicially independent order since the year 1912 .... After the Recollects obtained their complete separation from the Augustinian order in 1912, the friars of the discalced congregation discussed the possibility of complete union with the Augustinian order or with the new order of Recollects, but rejected both possibilities. In 1917 the discalced friars asked for themselves the same permission that had been given to the Recollects in 1911, namely the permission to call their superior no longer a vicar general but prior general. On January 3, 1918, the prefect of the Congregation for Religions, Cardinal Tonti, refused. Hence, the juridical bond was kept, even though few contacts remained.... The final move occurred in 1931, when the discalced Augustinians presented for approval to the Holy See their new constitutions which gave then name of prior general to the discalced superior, with all the privileges granted to the Augustinian order through the centuries. The Holy See gave its approval on April 1931. Hence, the Discalced Augustinians were from then on recognized as an autonomous order." (Cf. J. Gavigan, The Augustinians from the French Revolution to Modern Times (Villanova, PA: Augustinian Press, 1989), p.197-201.)
That said, there seems to be a long-standing tradition of using "Discalced Augustinians" as a synonym for "Augustinian Recollects". The 1913 edition of the Catholic Encylcopedia in its article on Augustinians introduces the Augustinian reform movement with the subheading: "The Discalced Augustinians -- (sometimes called the Barefooted Augustinians, or Augustinian Recollects)" and appears to conflate the development of the two orders. The 2nd ed. (2003), however, has a separate entry for the Augustinian Recollects but does not use the term "Discalced Augustinians" anywhere in it. (Similarly, the Discalced Augustinians, but not the Recollects, are mentioned briefly in the article on discalced orders.) Oliver Kapsner, in his Catholic Religious Orders, 2nd ed. enlarged (Collegeville: St. John's Abbey, 1957), has separate, non-synonymizing entries for both the Recollects and the Discalced, though he does credit St. Thomas of Jesus (Alvarez de Andrade) as the founder of the Recollects. (The 2003 Catholic Encyclopedia assigns him to the Discalced.) On the other hand, Peter Day's Dictionary of Religious Orders (London: Burns & Oates, 2001), gives "Discalced Augustinians" as another name for the Augustinian Recollects. Augnet.org hedges: its page for the Augustinian Recollects is sub-headed, "Sometimes in the past called the Barefooted Augustinians, or Discalced Augustinians". Since both orders initially arose at the same historical moment, had a similar reforming impetus, and remained for a long time as "observantine" variants within the Augustinian order, it doesn't surprise me that they might have occasionally gotten confused or conflated. E.g., David Gutierrez, in v. 3 of of the History of the Order of St. Augustine, treats them together as observantines and seems to use the term "discalced" as a generic for both. (Cf. D. Gutierrez, The Augustinians from the Protestant Reformation to the Peace of Westphalia 1518-1648 (Villanova, PA: Augustinian Historical Institute, 1979), p. 101-103.) It looks as if the established heading gets its information on the synonymity of the Recollects and the Discalced from the 1913 Catholic Encyclopedia, one presumes as made available on CD-ROM since they don't cite the online version. (Unless I'm reading the 670 wrong here -- always a possibility!) Or the establisher may have noticed all these people synonymizing the two and be acknowledging it. I don't think it helps at all to continue equating the two orders, though, even when speaking historically. Do the Discalced Augustines need their own heading? Or would that simply muddy the waters further?

comment.author: 58584977@N05
comment.text:
Bah. I always find something else after I think I'm done. The Ricci Roundtable's entry for the Augustinian Recollects may have hold of the right end of the stick:
Until 1621 they were called the Congregation of Discalced Hermits of St. Augustine of Spain and the Indies. Afterwards they were known as the Order of the Hermit Recollects of St. Augustine until 1912, after which they became the Order of Recollects of St. Augustine (ORSA).
So they were briefly "Discalced" (1588-1621) and then became "Recollects" (1621-1912-present). Since this inscription is dated "1696," clearly it's the Discalced Augustinians proper (Ordo Fratrum Eremitarum Discalceatorum Sancti Augustini) who are meant and not their Recollect brethren. (Cf. the Discalced Augustinians' Ricci Roundtable entry, if interested.)

In 1848 he removed to New Orleans, L[ouisian]a., where he completed his studies at Tulane University, and was admitted to the bar in 1852. He was a representative in the state legislature of Louisiana (1856-57); first justice of the peace for the parish of Orleans (1858-62); mayor of Carrollton, La. Although Judge Brice has been active in his profession, successfully managing a large practice, he has found time for the study of scientific and literary subjects, in the former of which he takes great interest, especially anthropology, astronomy, geology, evolution and cognate branches. He is a member of the American Association for the Advancement of Science and American Bar Association, and a 33d degree Mason. comment.text:
Oh dear - I just saw this and 3 months have passed since you posted last.  Take my email - it is scoutandhuck@yahoo.com.

I have his obit and birth/death certificates in my office and can get you that info by Friday some time.  He was also instrumental in bringing Carnival to New Orleans.  My grandmother, Rosie Brice West was Queen of Rex in 1911.  We donated her jewels and photos and dress, etc. to the Louisiana State Museum and last time we were down there it was all on display just off the square in the Pontalba or Cabildo buildings there.  It seems she was installed at the last moment b/c of AGBrice's influence, and the woman who was supposed to be queen (chosen way in advance in secret) had a death in the family and had to go into mourning. So my grandmother was put in in her place.  The family shunned publicity which is why there isn't much on him.

His obit, if you want a copy, is available at the Historic New Orleans Collection in the French Quarter as I recall.  

So email me if you want to stay in touch or if you have other questions.  He was indeed a Mason and we have his pin to prove it.  Aparently he and his wife (my great great grandmother) were asked to leave NOLA by General Butler when he began his occupation of New Orleans during the war.

Well, that's enough for now.  Let me know if  there is more you can use.

"à", and there is a town in Italy, while currently named Bastia Umbra, with an interesting potential French influence (and given the probably dating of the stamp, it's *possible*?), at least between the years 1808 and 1816: "Nel 1614 Bastia si dava un proprio statuto, staccandosi così per sempre dal comune di Assisi. Nel 1808 insieme al resto dell'Umbria, fu invasa dall'esercito di Napoleone; nel 1816 ritornò sotto lo Stato Pontificio, finché nel 1861 entrò a far parte del Regno d'Italia. Nel 1832 e nel 1854 gravi terremoti colpirono anche Bastia, come altri centri dell'Umbria, provocando ingenti danni alle abitazioni ed agli edifici pubblici. Nel 1926 prese il nome di Bastia Umbra, per distinguerla da altre località aventi lo stesso toponimo. [although other wikipedia pages -- english, french, et al.(?) -- state that Umbra was added upon Italian unification in 1861] anyway, interesting, perhaps, if nothing else...

comment.author: 58558794@N07
comment.text:
I am paying the price for not recording any of the research I initially did on this stamp.  When I first loaded the picture, I put in tags for Jesuits and Jesuit stamps.  Whatever it was that I discovered later led me to believe that it couldn't be Jesuit, so I removed them.  I no longer know why--perhaps I could find no evidence of Jesuit activity in Bastia?  Whatever the reason, I decided that the IHS was just generic Catholic rather than SJ.  Wish I knew why.
I lean very heavily towards the Corsican Bastia--Napoleon got around, but his lasting legacy in the places that no longer wanted him seems to be an appreciation of good champagne rather than street names in French.

comment.author: 58654589@N08
comment.text: well, to respond to the Jesuit activity in Corsica, at least according to the "Catholic encyclopedia" (and overtly ignoring any issue of dates and specific locations): books.google.com/books?id=2GcQAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA397&l... but you're right, I have no real positive evidence that it is a Jesuit Christogram, so I'll remove the Jesuit heading from the catalog record

comment.author: 58558794@N07
comment.text:
From your Catholic Encyclopedia citation:
"Before the suppression of the religious orders"--what is this?  At first I assumed the Jesuit suppression in 1768, but it seems to refer to an event closer to the publication of the book (1908), and this suppression affected all religious orders, not just Jesuits.  The passage is mostly about the effects of the separation of church and state in Corsica, so perhaps it is one of those laws that consititutes the "suppression of the religious orders".
Anyway, all that to say that if the suppression is ca. 1908, and that the Jesuits left Corsica around then, it is unlikely that this is their stamp, because it looks 20th century to me (although you would be a better judge than I).  Nevertheless, I'm putting them back in to the tags!
Christogram was the word I was looking for.

comment.author: 58584977@N05
comment.text: First inscription: Anno d[omi]nj mil[lesim]o cccco s[e]xig[esim]o [sic?] nono declaratum est in consilio basiliensi beatissim{am?} vi[r]gine[m?] nu[m]q[uam] [...] peccato originali quod semper [...] verum[?] l[...] [...] [...] co[n]silij determinatione[m?] plures aliter [...] [...] processu semp[...] quod[?] se[m]per suis [...] [...] resolutione co[n]clusum est spiritu[?] [...] [...] [I'll hazard that the first hand is recording the approbation of the Doctrine of the Immaculate Conception by the Council of Basel on 18 December 1439. (I'm guessing that "AD 1469" in line one is an error for "1439" because the Council of Basel ran from 1431-1445.) This approbation never "took" in the church at large because the Council's authoritative status was undermined by its subsequent deposition of Pope Eugene IV and appointment of the anti-pope Felix V. The doctrine wasn't formally promulgated as dogma until 1854, though the Council of Basel's statement on the matter was often used to support it.]

Catalogus inscriptus anno 1603") or a provenance note (like in our inscription "ex dono"). It also seems to appear in the form "Catalogo inscriptus" .Cf. this google book. comment.author: 58558794@N07
comment.text: D'azur, à trois fusées d'or accolées en fasce Azure, three lozenges conjoined in fess or (or some approximation thereof, my heraldic vocabulary is terrible) Could be Bouthillier de Chavigny, (see Au blason des armoiries website here under Fusée) but I haven't yet found a member of the family who is marquis and chevalier des ordres du roy. Léon Bouthillier, Chevalier, Comte de Chavigny et de Buzançais is an officer in the Ordre du Saint Esprit, but is only comte. I don't know whether subsequent members of the family would have automatically continued in the the order (it doesn't seem like it would be hereditary), but if so, it would eventually have passed to whichever Chavigny became marquis. There is a VIAF heading for Bouthillier Chavigny, Charles Léon,|cmarquis de,|d1743-1818 but I don't see his name listed in the Ordre du Saint Esprit. I originally tagged this as an author's device (based on a bookseller's description, I think). It definitely is not that--the author is Giangiorgio Trissino, who is not French, not a marquis, and not even alive when the Order of the Holy Spirit was founded (1578).

The marquisat was established during the reign of Louis XIV Dictionnaire de la noblesse ... by Francois Alexandre Aubert de La Chesnaye Des Bois entry for Bouthillier Chavigny family here

comment.text: That seems to be right (my heraldic vocabulary is far worse...), see also: Léon Quantin: "Ex-libris héraldiques anonymes.'' Paris: E. Paul et fils et Guillemin, 1907, p. 31 books.google.com/books?id=aXBBAAAAYAAJ "Bouthlllier de Chavigny. — Bretagne, XVIIe siècle. 182. — D'azur à trois fusées d'or, accolées en fasce. Couronne de duc." The crown, however, is definitely not a french ducal crown - (the three pearls in a row are marquis old style) but Quantin may be wrong here.

comment.author: 58584977@N05
comment.text:
Michel Popoff's Armorial de l'Ordre du Saint-Esprit (Paris: Leopard d'Or, 1996), gives two members of the order with this blazon (nos. 885-886; cf. 941-942) :
Claude Bouthillier, chevalier, seigneur de Pont-sur-Seine et de Fossigny, secrétaire d'Etat, surintendant des finances, grand trésorier des Ordres du Roi par lettres du 27 mars 1633, mort en 1651. Léon Bouthillier, chevalier, comte de Chavigny et de Buzançais, secrétaire et ministre d'Etat, grand trésorier des Ordres du Roi, mort 11 octobre 1652, âge de 44 ans.
Claude (1581-1652) was a diplomat and associate of Cardinal Richelieu (and one of his executors); Wikipedia calls him "Sieur de Fouilletourte." Léon (1608-1652), his son, was also a diplomat and served as secretary of state for foreign affairs under Louis XIII until 1643. Both men have VIAF entries, Léon here (in which the Vatican Library mistakenly identifies him as a duke, but the Germans don't) and Claude here. The Armorial des Chevaliers du Saint-Esprit at heraldique-europeenne.org pictures the arms of both men here -- neither with the coronet pictured in our image. On the whole, I'm inclined to identify these arms with Léon Bouthillier, comte de Chavigny, as Claude never seems to have risen high enough to warrant any kind of fancy coronet and no other members of the Bouthillier family were also chevaliers of the Ordre (at least as far as I can tell). Side note: Léon's son Armand Jean le Bouthillier de Rancé (1626-1700) founded the Trappists.

comment.text: Franciscus di guiciardinis de florentia accipit a d[omi]no Ambrosio dono. Very possibly Francesco Guicciardini (1483-1540), Italian Florentine historian, papal statesman, and friend of Niccolò Machiavelli. Established heading: Guicciardini, Francesco, ǂd 1483-1540.

comment.author: 58584977@N05
comment.text: It occurs to me to wonder, too, whether "Dominus Ambrosius" is the Dominican theologian Lancelotto Politi (1483-1553), whose name in religion was "Ambrosius Catharinus." Already a doctor of laws, he entered the Dominican order in 1513 in Florence and went on to serve as Bishop of Minori (1546-1552) and Archbishop of Conza (1552-1553). I have no way to prove this, but just in case ... Established heading: Ambrosius Catharinus, ǂc Archbishop of Conza, ǂd 1484-1553.

comment.author: 58584977@N05
comment.text: Described in The Library Chronicle of the Friends of the University of Pennsylvania Library XXVI (1961), p. 84, as "a thirty-two line Latin poem in manuscript addressed to Cardinal Alessandro Farnese" by the "enigmatic" M. Spi., author of the printed text to which this ms. has been added. The poem appears to honor (or at least to mention repeatedly) Pope Julius III (1487-1555; papacy 1550-1555), born Giovanni Maria Ciocchi del Monte. He succeeded Pope Paul III (1468-1549; papacy 1534-1549), also born Alessandro Farnese. The poem's dedicatee, Paul III's grandson Alessandro Cardinal Farnese, was a power broker in the conclave which elected Julius III as a compromise candidate. (Aside: I want to read an alternate history in which Reginald Pole became the first English Pope since Adrian IV.) Established form: Farnese, Alessandro, ǂd 1520-1589. Established form: Julius ǂb III, ǂc Pope, ǂd 1487-1555. Established form: Paul ǂb III, ǂc Pope, ǂd 1468-1549.

comment.text: Basilij Zanchij ad Io chrysostomu[m] fratrem Dum frater german[...] [...]s chrysostom[...] chartis Cenomanu[m] gentes texis et orobies Dum titulos, dum facta refers, dum C[a]esaris arma, Parta[que] pugnaci veg[...] superba manu Qua cynips[?] Libyea arua[?] vigas, qua culta Tune[...] Cornigero fuma[n]t qua sua [...]ura Ioui[?] Dum Patriam scriptis celebras, tibi gloria surgit Clara [...]uc est ipso C[a]esari fama minor. [Laudatory verse by Basilio Zanchi (1501-ca. 1558) for his brother Giovanni Crisostomo Zanchi (d. 1566). Both brothers joined the Canons Regular of the Lateran. Basilio was a poet and protege of Leo X; unfortunately, he fell foul of Paul IV for refusing to remain in his monastery and was imprisoned in Rome in 1558. He is supposed to have died there. Giovanni Crisostomo outlived him and indeed rose to become head of their order in 1559. His historical work De Orobiorum seu Cenomanorum Origine Libri Tres is praised in this poem. Established form: Zanchi, Basilio, ǂd 1501-ca. 1558.]

comment.author: 58584977@N05
comment.text: Leaf from a liturgical ms., probably a gradual, with text and music for the offertorium ("Posuisti, Domine, in capite eius coronam de lapide pretioso: vitam petiit a te, et tribuisti ei, alleluia.") and communio ("Qui mihi ministrat me sequatur: et ubi ego sum, illic et minister meus erit.") of the common of a martyr (cf. heading "UNIUS MART:"). Music (clefs, neumes and 4-line staves) and text in brown ink; headline, initial, rubric and vertical lines in red ink. Folio or page number(?) in upper left corner in brown ink. Post-Gothic hand.

comment.author: 58584977@N05
comment.text: Woodcut diagram of the faculties of the soul from Johann Horst vom Romberch's Congestorium artificiose memorie (Venice: Melchiorre Sessa, 1533). Cf. F.A. Yates, The Art of Memory (London: Pimlico, 1992), p. 251-252.

comment.author: 58584977@N05
comment.text: Woodcut illustration from Johann Horst von Romberch's work on memory, Congestorium artificiose memorie (Venice: Melchiorre Sessa, 1533). "A memory locus which is to contain a memory image must not be larger than a man can reach; this is illustrated by a cut of a human image on a locus, reaching upwards and sideways to demonstrate the right proportions of the locus in relation to the image."--F.A. Yates, The Art of Memory (London: Pimlico, 1992), p. 124.

comment.author: 58584977@N05
comment.text: Woodcut of an abbey and its associated buildings as a mnemonic device, used by Melchiorre Sessa of Venice in his 1533 printing of the Dominican Johann Horst von Romberch's Congestorium artificiose memorie. Cf. F.A. Yates, The Art of Memory (London: Pimlico, 1992), p. 115-116.

comment.author: 58584977@N05
comment.text: Associated image: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/58558794@N07/5949759519/]

comment.author: 58584977@N05
comment.text: Woodcut explicating the abbey memory system of the Dominican Johann Horst von Romberch in his Congestorium artificiose memorie (Venice: Melchiorre Sessa, 1533). In this cut are "sets of objects to be memorized in the courtyard, library, and chapel of the abbey. Each fifth place is marked with a hand and each tenth place with a cross, in accordance with the instructions given in [the popular rhetorical textbook] Ad Herennium for distinguishing the fifth and tenth places. Obviously there is an association here with the five fingers. As Memory moved along the places, these were ticked off on the fingers."--F.A. Yates, The Art of Memory (London: Pimlico, 1992), p. 116.

comment.author: 58584977@N05
comment.text: Associated image: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/58558794@N07/5949759359]

comment.author: 58584977@N05
comment.text: Woodcut diagram of a portion of a visual alphabet from Johann Horst von Romberch's work on memory, Congestorium artificiose memorie (Venice: Melchiorre Sessa, 1533). "Visual alphabets are ways of representing letters of the alphabet by images. These are formed in various ways; for example with pictures of objects whose shape resemble [sic] letters of the alphabet, as compasses or a ladder for A; or a hoe for N. Another way is through pictures of animals or birds arranged in the order of the first letter of their names, as A for Anser, goose, B for Bubo, owl."--F.A. Yates, The Art of Memory (London: Pimlico, 1992), p. 124-125.

comment.author: 58584977@N05
comment.text: Woodcut illustration of Grammar as a memory image from Johann Horst von Romberch's work on memory, Congestorium artificiose memorie (Venice: Melchiorre Sessa, 1533). "This is one of the very rare cases in which memory image is illustrated; and the image turns out to be the familiar figure of old Grammatica, the first of the liberal arts, with some of her familiar attributes, the scalpel and the ladder. She is here not only the well-known personification of the liberal art of Grammar, but a memory image being used to remember material about grammar through inscriptions on her. The inscription across her chest and the images near or on her are derived from Romberch's visual alphabeths, both the 'objects' ones and the 'birds' one which he is using in combination."--F.A. Yates, The Art of Memory (London: Pimlico, 1992), p. 126.

comment.author: 71586127@N00
comment.text: Brilliant.  But while I love the illustration, the image isn't unpacked.  Why are Grammar's tools the scalpel and ladder?  To cut away, and to climb towards understanding?  What are the tools on the ladder for? Her arms are for Negation and Affirmation... what are the things on her chest? Can you unpack this image some more, please?

comment.author: 58584977@N05
comment.text:
Correction: The established W. Pratt is a late 19th-early 20th(?)-century bookbinder whose name usually appears in conjunction with that of H. Stevens in the form: "Bound by W. Pratt for H. Stevens [date]". "W. Pratt" appearing alone is frequently identified as the London bookseller and binder William Pitt Pratt, (fl. 1823-1839), but BBTI also gives three other possibilities:
William Pratt (d. 1833), London bookbinder William Pratt (fl. 1829), London bookbinder William Pratt (fl. ca. 1840-ca. 1860), Birmingham printer, stationer, bookseller, bookbinder and newsagent
More information needed to establish which one our "W. Pratt" is.

comment.author: 34477364@N07
comment.text: J. B. Inglis had the curious habit of cutting out ("vignetting") pictorial or symbolic material from other old books or prints and mounting them in his books, as here.  It would perhaps be of interest to determine whether these cut-outs bear any relationship to the works in which they are inserted.

comment.author: 58584977@N05

comment.author: 58584977@N05
comment.text: Arms and motto of a priest? Cf. the old Catholic Encyclopedia article "Eccesiastical heraldry" for an explanation. Basically the hat itself signifies a churchman, while its color and number of tassels indicate his rank. A black hat with one tassel on each side is a priest's.

comment.author: 58584977@N05
comment.text: Illustration of an enthroned Holy Roman Emperor wearing the Imperial Crown of Austria and holding its associated sceptre and orb; a shield with the Habsburg arms sits at his feet. If a historical figure and not a generic one, it cannot be any ruler earlier than the Habsburg Holy Roman Emperor Matthias (1557-1619), for whom the sceptre and orb were made, the crown having been created for his brother and predecessor Rudolf II (1552-1612).

comment.author: 58584977@N05
comment.text:
Woodcut coats of arms.
Center: Arms of Maximilian I Habsburg (1459-1519), Holy Roman Emperor from 1493 until his death. Top left: Arms of Austria. Top right: Arms of Styria? (Vert, a panther rampant argent incensed proper.) Bottom left: Arms of Carinthia? (If so, in mirror image -- possibly an error by the blockcutter?) Bottom right: Arms of Carniola (that is, if the bit across the breast of the eagle is a "crescent chequy gules and or." If not, then it's either Tyrol [a red eagle] or Friuli [a gold eagle], both uncharged.)
Used by Hieronymus Vietor and Johann Singriener of Vienna.

comment.text: Illustration of a well-dressed humanoid figure with the eyes of a lynx, the ears of a pig, the neck of a swan or snake, and the right foot of a bear. A lion's head is on its breast; from its mouth protrude a sword and a spray of lily leaves. The figure holds a closed purse in its right hand and is dropping coins from its left. The woodcut is by Hans Sebald Beham. For analysis, see M. Curschmann, "Facies peccatorum -- Vir bonus: Bild-Text-Formeln zwischen Hochmittelalter und früher Neuzeit" in Poesis et Pictura, ed. S. Füssel and J. Knape (Baden-Baden: V. Koerner, 1989), p. 157-189.

comment.author: 58584977@N05
comment.text: Gift inscription from Alfred Eberhard (1841-1914) either to Karl Friedrich Ernst Koldewey, known as Friedrich Koldewey (1839-1909; educator and historian), or his son Friedrich Koldewey (1866-1940; principal of Werner-von-Siemens-Gymnasium, Bad Harzburg, Germany, 1894-1929), dated 25 April 1884 in Braunschweig, Germany. On balance, I favor the elder Koldewey whose birthday is 26 April and who arrived in Braunschweig in 1884 to head the Herzogliches Realgymnasium. Established heading: Koldewey, Friedrich, ǂd 1839-1909. Established heading: Koldewey, Friedrich, ǂd b. 1866. Established heading: Eberhard, Alfred, ǂd 1841-1914.

comment.author: 58584977@N05
comment.text: In Georgio Schermero p[re]ceptori suo obseruandiss. d[ono] d[edit] [Possibly Georg Schermer (d. 1597). Per VIAF, he was a theologian, educator and pastor, with appointments at the Universität Greifswald as a professor of theology and at a school at Stargard in Pommern (now Stargard Szczeciński, Poland) as rector. In Isaac Lelong's Hondertjaarige jubelgedachtenisse der akademie van Utrecht (Amsterdam: Vieroot, 1736), p. 196, "Georgius Schermerus" is stated to have founded the school at Stargard in 1549; the Hausbuch des Herrn Joachim von Wedel, ed. Julius Freiherr von Bohlen Bohlendorff (Tübingen, 1882), p. 210, confirms that he is "rector scholae" there in 1565. Again per VIAF, he also appears to have held a pastorate in Stargard.]

In Isaac Lelong's Hondertjaarige jubelgedachtenisse der akademie van Utrecht (Amsterdam: Vieroot, 1736), p. 196, "Georgius Schermerus" is stated to have founded the school at Stargard in 1549; the Hausbuch des Herrn Joachim von Wedel, ed. Julius Freiherr von Bohlen Bohlendorff (Tübingen, 1882), p. 210, confirms that he is "rector scholae" there in 1565. Again per VIAF, he also appears to have held a pastorate in Stargard.]

comment.author: 58584977@N05
comment.text: A conventional grouping from the Quaternionsystem, popularized in the mid-15th century, which ordered the foremost or fundamental components of the Holy Roman Empire into 10 groups of four: Herzöge (dukes), Markgrafen (margraves), Landgrafen (landgraves), Burggrafen (burgraves), Grafen (counts), Freiherren (barons), Ritter (knights), Städte (cities), Dörfer (towns), and Bauern (smaller towns). Cf. B. Schneidmüller, Die Kaiser des Mittelalters, 2nd ed., (Munich: Beck, 2007), p. 112.

comment.author: 58584977@N05
comment.text: The dukedoms are a conventional grouping from the Quaternionsystem, popularized in the mid-15th century, which ordered the foremost or fundamental components of the Holy Roman Empire into 10 groups of four: Herzöge (dukes), Markgrafen (margraves), Landgrafen (landgraves), Burggrafen (burgraves), Grafen (counts), Freiherren (barons), Ritter (knights), Städte (cities), Dörfer (towns), and Bauern (smaller towns). Cf. B. Schneidmüller, Die Kaiser des Mittelalters, 2nd ed., (Munich: Beck, 2007), p. 112.

comment.author: 65703354@N08
comment.text: I'd love to know more about this one. Seems to be part of some sort of library associated with the government of the Barons of Rehlingen Hainhofen [Freiherrn von Rehlingen zu Hainhofen] in the Augsburg area. The crest matches theirs - see www.deutschesfachbuch.de/info/detail.php?isbn=3896394282. I think the stamp reads "Freih.v.Rehling. Rentenverwaltung Hain-Hofen" I'm getting some sort of payment (pension) administration as a literal translation but I imagine this could be another kind of municipal organization.

comment.author: 24896977@N04
comment.text: I agree with your reading. Apparently "Rentenverwaltung" was a term used in Bavaria for the feudal  administration office that dealt with hereditary land and the income from it. My guess (!) is that it somewhat worked like a Fideicommiss (i.e. its assets were not considered personal property but trust holdings), and that's why the book is stamped by the Rentenverwaltung rather than with a personal stamp - a book on comedies is not really something you would expect in a financial office ;-)

(Plautus is always a good read, and no doubt could have provided much needed comic relief after long days in the financial office!)

comment.author: 58584977@N05
comment.text: The Rehlingen zu Hainhofen line appears to have its official start with Marx Conrad von Rehlingen (1575-1642), originally just plain (but substantial!) "Rehlinger" of Augsburg and ennobled as "von Rehlingen" in 1604. Hainhofen came to him through his wife, Magdalena (née Paler), whose family purchased it from the Fuggers. (Cf. A. Steichele, ed., Archiv für die Geschichte des Bisthums Augsburg (Augsburg: B. Schmid'sche Verlagsbuchhandlung, 1859), v. 2, p. 355.) The family established an entail (a "Fideikommiss" according to the Staatsarchiv Augsburg) in the mid-18th century to preserve its property, evidently including its library. Most recently, Fritz von Rehlingen (1911-1999), an archivist at the Staatsarchiv München, donated an archive of family papers to Bavaria and in 2003 it became part of the collection of the Staatsarchiv Augsburg as the Herrschaftsarchiv Hainhofen, Freiherren von Rehlingen. (Cf. P. Fleischmann, "Archive der Freiherren von Rehlingen im Staatsarchiv Augsburg erschlossen," Nachrichten aus den Staatlichen Archiven Bayerns 55 (2008):26.) As with so many of these Germany family libraries, interest in explaining the legal means by which it was established appears ... limited. (There's a project for some enterprising student of law/library science!)

comment.author: 58584977@N05
comment.text: Very possibly Anne Morris Stout (d. 1900), granddaughter of Lewis Morris, signer of the Declaration of Independence, whose armorial bookplate has a burning castle for its crest and uses the motto "Tandem vincitur." In 1827 Anne married businessman Aquila Giles Stout (d. 1846), later president of the Eagle Fire Insurance Co. They had two children, Francis Aquila Stout (1833-1892) and Sarah Morris Stout (1836?-1904; later De Vaugrigneuse, having married Baron Ancelis de Vaugrigneuse, a French chargé d'affaires). The laudatory biography Francis Aquila Stout by Nadal, Read and Taylor (New York: 1894), p. 31 has this to say of his mother: "[Anne Morris Stout] was and is one of the most remarkable women of her generation. Possessing an original genius which was inherent in all of the older generations of the Morris family, she added to the powers of an active mind the accumulations of a spirit cultivated with indomitable energy from infancy to age. There was no subject too small, there was no question too large, for her observation and analysis. Enjoying a wide acquaintance in the most cultured as well as the most fashionable circles of New York, which were largely recruited from her own family and its connections, she maintained an influence and a supremacy in society which were undisputed." Sounds like someone who would have owned books ...

comment.text: Armorial bookplate of Caleb Fiske Harris (1818-1881) of Rhode Island, businessman and book collector. He graduated from Brown in 1834 and died with his wife in a canoeing accident in Maine in 1881. The bulk of his books were purchased by his cousin Henry Bowen Anthony, who sold those duplicated in his own collection and left the rest upon his death to Brown University. Cf. the Brown University Library web pages relating to the Harris Collection of American Poetry and Plays. Established form: Harris, Caleb Fiske, ǂd 1818-1881.

58584977@N05
comment.text:
Henry Houston Bonnell (1859-1926) was an 1880 Penn graduate (Class Prophet and recipient of the Spoon Award; cf. the Record for his year). After earning his BA, he worked for some years in publishing before retiring to concentrate on literary scholarship and philanthropy. His collection of works by and related to the Brontë family went after his death to the Brontë Parsonage Museum. A. Edward Newton, who advised both Bonnell and his widow to make the bequest, wrote of him:
Many years ago, nearer fifty than forty, I had a friend -- he is dead now -- who, like myself, was a member of a little club which devoted itself to the study of English literature. His name was Henry Houston Bonnell; unlike myself, he was not only pious, but good, really good. When I first knew him he was not rich, but he inherited wealth, and in between the various philanthropic activities to which he devoted his life he became a book-collector and a student of the English novel. He concealed from his friends -- at least from me -- the fact that he wrote hymns. I am glad of this. (Derby Day and Other Adventures (Boston: Little, Brown, 1934), p. 298-299)

comment.text: From JDG's sale 1854 Bought of Moline -- 3.15.0 by CDG From Cecil Dunn Gardner's Sale 1880 [?] NEB - These ms. notes are most likely of or referring to John Dunn Gardner and his brother, Cecil Dunn Gardner, both book collectors who shared the custom of penciling the date of purchase on the endleaf of their books. John's library was sold in 1854, and Cecil's library was sold by Sotheby's in 1880. Cf. English Collectors of Books and Manuscripts: (1530-1930) and Their Marks of Ownership, by Seymour De Ricci and www.oldandsold.com/articles11/book-prices-7.shtml Cecil is not established in VIAF, dates are 1827-c. 1880. Established heading for John, who lived 1811-1903: Gardner, John Dunn I cannot read the light pencil ms. notes at the top of this leaf (except maybe the first line [P. Hoff]) but that might be John Dunn's original notes from when he purchased this book?

comment.author: 65030572@N05
comment.text: "Honesto & docto Viro Dno [Domino] Nicolao Horn Senatori Reip. Oppenheimensis, amico suo in primis colendo, Abra: ham Scheiblieb Mismasis 18 July ao [anno] 78 misit." "Honorable and learned lord Nicholas Horn Senator of the commonwealth of Oppenheim, his friend in the highest esteem, Abraham Sheiblieb of Misma, sent 18 July of the year '78." An inscription to Nicholas Horn of a book sent to him by a dear friend, Abraham Sheiblieb. The place names are somewhat obscure. There is an Oppenheim in southwest Germany, but it was never part of anything resembling a commonwealth, nor did it ever belong to a political entity with a Senate. There is also an Oppenheim in Fulton County, New York, and it is possible that Nicholas Horn was the name of some past member of the upper house of the New York State legislature. I have been unable to find a list of past members of the New York State Senate to explore this possibility -- one must exist, but perhaps not on any website. I have not been able to find a Misma nor Milma in any gazetteer.

comment.author: 58584977@N05
comment.text: Honesto & docto Viro D[omi]ni Nicolao Horn Senatori Reip. Oppenheimensis amico suo imprimis c[...]lendo [...] Abra= ham Scheiblich Misinensis 18 Julii a[nn]o 78 misit[?] [Gift inscription from Abraham Scheiblich of Meissen to Nicolaus Horn of Oppenheim, dated 18 July 1578. Horn was born in Bremen and is listed in the Matrikel of the Universität Heidelberg in 1571; he served on the Oppenheim city council as late as 1595. Cf. S. Düll, Die Inschriften der Stadt Oppenheim (Weisbaden: Reichert, 1984), p. 81. Scheiblich, a scholarship student at Wittenberg, was interrogated at Torgau during the crypto-Calvinist controversy there in 1574; he initially resisted signing the Torgauer Artikel (a statement of Lutheran orthodoxy), but two days' imprisonment and the threatened loss of his scholarship changed his mind. Cf. H.-P. Hasse, Zensur theologischer Bücher in Kursachsen im konfessionellen Zeitalter (Leipzig: Evangelische Verlagsanstalt, 2000), p. 174, 358, 425, and R. Calinich, Kampf und Untergang des Melanchthonismus in Kursachsen in den Jahren 1570 bis 1574 (Leipzig: Brockhaus, 1866), p. 168.]

comment.author: 65030572@N05
comment.text: "von Liepmannsohn - Berlin. "5te April 1881.-- "(ohne Einband) -- 5 m. 50 [Unintelligible line] ":/ Ausgabe von 1590 besass fleijse /: "Jeroinus III, p. 131 "Die Ausgabe vom Jahre 1622! "angesetzt von Stargardt (Catalog "n:136 n:540) mit ... 15 mk." Translation: "from Liepmannsohn - Berlin "5th April 1881. "(without binding) 5 m 50 [perhaps a price: 5 Marks, 50 pfennigs?] [Unintelligible Line] "(Edition of 1590 border "fleijse") "Jeroinus III, page 131 "The edition from the year 1622! "Price quoted from Stargardt (Catalog no. 136 no. 540) with ... 15 marks." This inscription refers to two well-known antiquarian booksellers in Berlin in the 1880s, Leo Liepmannsohn, who dealt with both rare books and musical manuscripts, and Joseph A. Stargardt (1822-1885), who published over 150 stock and auction catalogs for both rare books and autographs in his life. I would interpret the beginning of the inscription to refer to the book in which it is found -- and describing that it was acquired by the owner from Liepmannsohn. The reference to a "fleijse border" exceeds the capabilities of my German dictionary. Perhaps it is some sort of technical bookbinding term. It may also be that the catalog reference to the 1622 Edition of "Jeroinus III" may be to a item in Stargardt's catalog number 136. Since the Stargardt firm is still in existence, perhaps they would know if there was an item no. 540 in catalog no. 136. Sources: www.stargardt.de/en/history/

comment.author: 24982336@N04
comment.text: von Liepmannsohn - Berlin. 5ter April 1881.-- (ohne Einband) -- 5 m. 50 [Unintelligible line] :/ Ausgabe von 1590 besass Heyse /: --> edition of 1590 was owned by Heyse Gervinus III, p. 131 Die Ausgabe vom Jahre 1622! angesetzt von Stargardt (Catalog n:136 n:540) mit ... 15 mk." Heyse is probably Heyse, Paul, 1830-1914 Gervinus is Gervinus, Georg Gottfried, 1805-1871: Geschichte der poetischen National-Literatur der Deutschen. vol 3 (1838), p 131 Stargard catalog 136 no 540 refers to the 1622 edition of Calvins Der Heylig Brotkorb Der Heil. Römischen Reliquien.

comment.author: 58584977@N05
comment.text: Booklabel of John Wolfran Cornwall (1870-1947) of the Cornwall family of Burford Lodge, Elstead, Surrey, England. He was born in Dehra, India (his father, William Wolfran Gardner Cornwall, was a member of the Bengal Civil Service) and attended Trinity College, Cambridge, obtaining a BA in 1891 and a MB (Bachelor of Medicine), BC and MA in 1895. He took his MD in 1900. Cornwall entered the Indian Medical Service in 1896 and rose to the rank of Lieutenant-Colonel. He served as Professor of Hygiene at Madras Medical College, Chennai, India, from 1903-1906, and director of the Pasteur Institute of India, Coonoor, Tamil Nadu, India, from 1906 until his retirement in 1926. In 1927 he was awarded a CIE (Companion of the Most Eminent Order of the Indian Empire). He married Effie Esmé Sinclair in 1904 and they had at least one child (a daughter). Cf. his entry in Venn and Venn, Alumni Cantabrigienses, pt. 1, vol. 2 (Cambridge: Cambridge UP, 1922), p. 140 and information on his family in C.G.S. Foljambe and C. Reade, The House of Cornewall (Hereford: Jakeman and Carver, 1908), p. 260-261; also the Cornwall family papers at the Surrey History Centre archives.

comment.author: 58584977@N05
comment.text: Armorial bookplate of John Cornwall. This could belong to the John Wolfran Cornwall of the booklabel, but it might also be that of his grandfather, Rear Admiral John Cornwall (1795-1870) or of his uncle John Cornwall (1826-1860). Cf. C.G.S. Foljambe and C. Reade, The House of Cornewall (Hereford: Jakeman and Carver, 1908), p. 260-261; also Rear Admiral Cornwall's obituary in Colburn's United Service Magazine (1870) pt. 3, p. 446.

Kirkland (New York: Parke-Bernet Galleries, 1962).

comment.author: 58584977@N05
comment.text:
Bookplate of John George Mortlock (1835-1917) of Meldreth, Cambridgeshire, UK. He ran the family china business in London; cf. this advertisement for "Mortlock's Pottery Galleries, founded A.D. 1746 in The Cambridge University Calendar for the Year 1891 (Cambridge: Deighton Bell & Co., 1891). See the Meldreth website for more information on the Mortlocks, including reminiscences by former staff such as gardener Bill Wing:
Mr [John George] Mortlock, who had a china shop in Oxford Street, used to go up to London every day by train -- he travelled first class! When he came home at night he would sometimes be irritable because he had gout -- he used to travel with a bottle of gin in his bag! On one occasion as I was helping him out of the train I grabbed his gouty leg and he bellowed at me, "Wing -- do you know what you are -- a bloody fool!" I replied, "Well, my mother didn’t have them all!"

comment.author: 58584977@N05
comment.text:
Woodcut depiction of the rosary (with printed instructions for prayer in Latin above) used by Friedrich Peypus of Nuremberg, with central figure of crucified Christ surmounted by God the Father and the Holy Spirit as a dove, with Madonna and Child Jesus at left and angel at right. To either side of the crucified Christ are three rows of figures:
Top left: Old Testament figures, including King David with harp and Moses with the tablets of the Law; also possibly St. John the Baptist pointing to a lamb(?). Top right: New Testament figures (St. Peter with keys; St. Paul with sword; symbols of the four Evangelists) Middle left: Male saints, possibly Church Fathers? Middle right: Male saints, probably Church Fathers, including Pope St. Gregory and St. Jerome with lion. Bottom left: Female saints, including St. Barbara with Cup and Host and St. Catherine with sword and wheel. Bottom right: Female saints.
The whole is surrounded by a rosary with flowers for beads and Maltese crosses marking the decades. At head of image (left to right): Pope St. Gregory? (the Eucharistic miracle); two angels supporting a cloth with the Holy Face of Jesus; an unidentified saint. At foot of image: Probably a depiction of Purgatory (note the figures being taken in hand by angels at left and right, as well as the praying figures in the flames).

comment.author: 65030572@N05
comment.text: I think that the two saints in the upper corners are St. Dominic (L) and St. Francis (R).  The figure next to St. Dominic is holding a staff and a book, symbols associated with St. Dominic (he is supposed to have received them from SS. Peter and Paul, respectively, in a vision in old St. Peter's Basilica).  St. Francis is supposed to have received the stigmata while contemplating a vision of a crucified six-winged seraph.  While it is, as one of your friends noted, hard to see if the figure St. Francis is looking at is a lily or a mosquito, this is a low-end Renaissance woodcut where lambs look like cats, so maybe the artist was a little at a loss as at how to render a crucified six-winged seraph.

comment.author: 58584977@N05
comment.text: I've become uncertain of the identification of the saint at top left as Pope St. Gregory because of the Tau cross there (usually associated with St. Francis). I'm not sure I want to call it St. Dominic, either: there's that cross, and the staff and book look to me like the generic accoutrements of an acolyte -- and the small figure rising from the altar on which the cup is placed, while the main figure kneels before it, says, "Eucharistic miracle!" to me, and I can't find one associated with St. Dominic. St. Bonaventure, a Franciscan, is supposed to have once received communion from the hand of an angel ... maybe it's him? (Except he wasn't presiding at Mass at the time, and the main figure looks as if he is to me ... argh.) I had considered St. Francis for the top right one for the reasons you state, but wasn't comfortable with that guess because usually the stigmata are depicted. On the other hand, what else could he be looking at? Cf. this image by Giotto. I'll add St. Francis to our tags.
